{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3531255,"name":"David Lame","username":"David_Lame","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/51bf81/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T07:16:05.653Z","cooked":"

Hello all. It’s our team’s first year using PhotonVision, and I really like it. However,

I have done the calibration with the camera, and I’m getting good results. My pose is accurate to about 3 inches. I was hoping for better, but maybe with some tuning and a Kalman filter…

But the problem is that I have calibrated multiple times, because I calibrate, and then do some tests, and I turn on and off the Raspberry Pi, and at some point, I try to enter 3d mode, and suddenly it’s not possible, because the camera that was calibrated before is no longer calibrated.

Is there something that has to be done to actually save and reuse the calibration?

I should note that I have reused it, a lot, multiple times. I calibrate. I check it. It’s still thate. I turn off the PI and Robot. Still there. All good. But at some point, I turn it on, and the camera calibration data is gone.

Any suggestions?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T07:16:05.653Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":93.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492143,"topic_slug":"photonvision-losing-calibration-data","display_username":"David Lame","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24723,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/photonvision-losing-calibration-data/492143/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3531299,"name":"","username":"Nummun14","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nummun14/{size}/254803_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T09:28:36.327Z","cooked":"

You can export the calibration by clicking on it and then clicking export. Then, if it doesn’t save you can import it.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T09:29:00.538Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":61,"readers_count":60,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492143,"topic_slug":"photonvision-losing-calibration-data","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63834,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5990 | Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/photonvision-losing-calibration-data/492143/2","custom_user_title":"5990 | Programmer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531797,"name":"David Lame","username":"David_Lame","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/51bf81/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T19:14:18.177Z","cooked":"

Thanks. That will save some inconvenience. I was aware that that feature existed, but I hadn’t used it.

What worries me is that it seems to be saving it. It works for a long time, including through power cycles. And then, suddenly, it’s gone. I’m a bit worried that it is also going to lose it during a match, leaving us without accurate vision data.

If I can programmatically import it at run time (i.e. during robot init tell it to use saved calibration data) that would solve the problem. I’ll look in the documentation to see if I can find anything about that.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T19:14:18.177Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":35,"readers_count":34,"score":12.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492143,"topic_slug":"photonvision-losing-calibration-data","display_username":"David Lame","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":63834,"username":"Nummun14","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nummun14/{size}/254803_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24723,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/photonvision-losing-calibration-data/492143/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531812,"name":"Sam","username":"Sam948","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sam948/{size}/261363_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T19:32:09.288Z","cooked":"

I don’t believe you’re able to programatically import a calibration. Something you should keep in mind is that calibrations only apply to a specific resolution, so it’s possible that you calibrated for one resolution, but then were using another. If that’s not the problem, I would really appreciate it if you could make an issue on github so we can try to help you resolve this.

Thanks. I’ll keep an eye on it, and if it happens again I’ll try to capture as much information on the specifics, and then start an issue.
